metadata.case_name: Four brothers from village Banat v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Applicants are four brothers holding land in village Banat, tahsil Kairana, District Muzaffarnagar.
Notification issued under section 4 of the Act in respect of 223 villages in tahsil Kairana, declaring that the State Government had decided to make a scheme of consolidation in that area.
Necessary action under various provisions of the Act resulting in a statement of proposals under section 19.
Objections to these proposals filed by the petitioners and others, decided in April 1956.
Petitioners went in appeal to the Settlement Officer Consolidation, decided in August 1957.
Present petition filed in this Court thereafter.
U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act No. VIII of 1939 passed, but of little effect as it could only be applied when more than one-third of proprietors applied.
Act passed by U.P. Legislature in 1953, received assent of President on March 4, 1954, published in gazette on March 8, 1954.
Declarations under section 4 made for major part of State including petitioners' village in July 1954.
Petitioner had lands in one chak of rental value Rs. 20-6-0 allotted Rs. 20-5-0; another chak Rs. 148-10-0 allotted Rs. 147-13-0; total loss land valued at Annas 0-14-0 (over half per cent).
Allahabad High Court held section 14(1)(ee) void under Article 31(2) pre-Fourth Amendment for no compensation; appeals pending.
Section 29-B enacted by Act XVI of 1957 with retrospective effect.

legal_issues.text: Section 6 read with section 4 gives arbitrary powers to State Government to accord discriminatory treatment by placing some villages under consolidation while excluding others, offending Article 14.

Sections 8, 9 and 10 read with section 49 provide procedure for correction and revision of revenue records vitally different from villages not under consolidation, discrimination offending Article 14.

Sections 14 to 17 read with section 49 confer arbitrary powers on consolidation authorities to deprive tenure-holder of land or rights, depriving protection of courts available to others, discrimination offending Article 14.
Sections 19 to 22 read with section 49 create discrimination on same grounds as sections 14 to 17, hit by Article 14.
Section 29-B provides inadequate compensation, hit by Article 31(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 6 with s.4 arbitrary power to cancel declaration even for part of area, discriminates between villages under and not under consolidation.
Ss.8,9,10 with s.49 provide different procedure for correction/revision of records vs. U.P. Land Revenue Act, barring civil/revenue courts jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; U.P. Land Revenue Act ss.40,41,51,54

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss.14-17 with s.49 confer arbitrary powers to deprive tenure-holders of land/rights without court protection available elsewhere.
Ss.19-22 with s.49 create same discrimination as ss.14-17.
S.29-B provides inadequate compensation (not fair market value).

respondent_arguments.text: Section 6 is restatement of power under General Clauses Act; high status of State Government and rules remove arbitrariness.

court_reasoning.text: Even if s.6 invalid, severable; does not affect petitioners; leave open for appropriate case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions severable; power of cancellation not inextricably mixed with ordering consolidation.

court_reasoning.text: Procedure under Ch.II shorter but provides notice, hearing, evidence, one appeal; rational classification for expeditious consolidation; disputes on title referred to arbitrator with Arbitration Act procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not arbitrary; essentials of natural justice; nexus to object of Act.

court_reasoning.text: Ch.III provides hearing by two officers; title disputes to arbitrator, final decision; necessary for timely consolidation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rational basis for classification with nexus to Act's object.

court_reasoning.text: Same reasons as for Ch.II apply to Ch.III; s.22(2) necessary to prevent delays from pending suits.

Compensation under s.29-B (4x hereditary rates for bhumidar, 2x for sirdar) adequate given small land taken (<1%), consolidated for public purposes benefiting tenure-holders directly (e.g., pastures, schools); plus benefits of compact holdings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cash plus direct advantages adequate under Art.31(2) pre-Fourth Amendment.

holdings.text: Ch. II provisions not discriminatory under Article 14.
Ch. III ss.14-17 not discriminatory under Article 14.
Ch. III ss.19-22 not discriminatory under Article 14.
Section 29-B provides adequate compensation under Article 31(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Allahabad High Court decisions on s.14(1)(ee)
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.14(1)(ee) void pre-s.29-B; appeals pending before Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1954 (U.P. V of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged as unconstitutional; upheld with scheme for consolidation operations.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for challenge; provisions not violated.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Revenue Act, 1901
statutes_cited.relevance: Ordinary procedure for records; contrasted with consolidation procedure.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1939 (No. VIII of 1939)
Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned re Art.31(2); not necessary to decide.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applicable to arbitrator proceedings under s.37.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Prevention of Fragmentation and Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1947 (Bom. LXII of 1947)

outcome.summary: All challenges to constitutionality of U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1954 and amendments rejected; provisions upheld under Articles 14 and 31(2); petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: Consolidation would result in improving agricultural production goes without saying and it was with the object of encouraging the development of agriculture that consolidation schemes with a compulsory character were taken up.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and benefits of the Act.

key_quotes.text: If consolidation is a boon to the tenure-holders of a village, as we hold it is, and if it is to be put through within a reasonable period of time, it is necessary to have a procedure which would be shorter than the ordinary procedure.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies differential procedure as reasonable classification.

key_quotes.text: The cash compensation, added to the advantages which the tenure-holders get in the large area of land thus constituted and on account of getting a compact block for themselves, is inadequate.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds compensation adequate considering direct benefits.
